title: Allergy Blood Test: MedlinePlus Medical Test
content:
**Allergy Blood Test**

An allergy blood test measures the amount of allergy-causing antibodies called immunoglobulin E (IgE). Antibodies are proteins that your immune system makes to fight foreign substances, such as viruses and bacteria.  But your immune system may also make them in response to allergens. These are harmless substances, such as pollen and peanuts, that may cause an allergic reaction in some people.

It's normal to have small amounts of IgE in your blood. But when you have an allergic reaction, your immune system sees the allergens as a threat and makes IgE antibodies. This increases the amount of IgE in your blood and causes your allergy symptoms.

**Common Allergens**

Pollen
Dust
Mold
Animal dander
Certain foods, including nuts and shellfish
Certain medicines, such as penicillin

Allergy symptoms can be mild to severe, depending on the type of allergy you have. They can range from itching and sneezing to asthma or even a life-threatening condition called anaphylactic shock.

**What is it used for?**

Allergy blood tests are used to help find out if you have an allergy. There are two general types of allergy blood tests:

*   A total IgE test measures the total amount of IgE antibodies in your blood.
*   A specific IgE test measures how much IgE your body makes in response to a single allergen. A separate test is done for each allergen that may be causing your allergies.

**Why do I need an allergy blood test?**

Your health care provider may order allergy testing if you have symptoms of an allergy. These include:

*   Stuffy or runny nose
*   Sneezing
*   Itchy, watery eyes
*   Hives (itchy raised red patches on your skin)
*   Diarrhea
*   Vomiting
*   Shortness of breath
*   Coughing
*   Wheezing

Your provider may order an allergy blood test if you can't have allergy skin testing. Skin testing involves putting allergens directly on or into your skin. You may not be able to have skin testing if you:

*   Have certain skin conditions
*   Take certain medicines that may affect the results of the test
*   Are likely to have a serious allergic reaction to the allergens used in skin testing

In certain cases, providers may order allergy blood tests for young children because skin testing may be too uncomfortable for them.

**What happens during an allergy blood test?**

A health care professional will take a blood sample from a vein in your arm, using a small needle. After the needle is inserted, a small amount of blood will be collected into a test tube or vial. You may feel a little sting when the needle goes in or out. This usually takes less than five minutes.

**Will I need to do anything to prepare for the test?**

You don't need any special preparations for an allergy blood test. You may need to stop taking certain medicines before this test, such as antihistamines, so tell your provider about everything you take. But don't stop taking any medicines unless your provider tells you to.

**Are there any risks to the test?**

There is very little risk to having an allergy blood test. You may have slight pain or bruising at the spot where the needle was put in, but most symptoms go away quickly.

**What do the results mean?**

A total IgE test result that is high means that you may have some kind of allergy. But the results of a total IgE test don't show what you're allergic to or how serious your allergy may be.

A specific IgE test result that is high means that you may be allergic to the allergen that was tested. But the amount of IgE measured doesn't predict how serious your allergy may be.

If the results from either type of test show that you could have an allergy, your provider may refer you to an allergy specialist or recommend a treatment plan. Your treatment plan will depend on what you are allergic to and how serious your symptoms are.

If you're at risk for anaphylactic shock, you'll need to be very careful to avoid the things you are allergic to. You may need to carry an emergency epinephrine treatment (an epinephrine auto-injector) with you at all times. Anaphylactic shock is most common with allergies to certain foods, medicines, insect bites and stings, and latex.

Ask your provider if you are at risk for anaphylactic shock and discuss any questions you have about your test results or your allergy treatment plan.

**Is there anything else I need to know about an allergy blood test?**

Allergy blood tests may not always be accurate. Sometimes, the results may say you have an allergy when you actually don't (also known as a false positive). This may happen if your body is having a slight reaction to substances in certain foods that you may have eaten before the test. Higher amounts of IgE may also be caused by smoking or a parasitic infection.

It's uncommon for a blood test to show that you don't have an allergy when you actually do (also known as a false negative).

Depending on your medical history and symptoms, your provider may order an allergy skin test with an allergy blood test, or you may have a skin test alone.

---

**Allergy Blood Test**

**What is an Allergy Blood Test?**

An allergy blood test measures the levels of allergen-specific IgE antibodies in your blood. This type of test can help determine if you have allergies and what you may be allergic to.

**When is an Allergy Blood Test Ordered?**

Your health care provider may order an allergy blood test if you have symptoms of an allergy, such as:

* Stuffy or runny nose
* Sneezing
* Itchy, watery eyes
* Hives (itchy raised red patches on your skin)
* Diarrhea
* Vomiting
* Shortness of breath
* Coughing
* Wheezing

Your provider may also order an allergy blood test if you can't have allergy skin testing due to certain skin conditions, medications that may affect the results, or young children who may find skin testing uncomfortable.

**What Happens During an Allergy Blood Test?**

A health care professional will take a blood sample from a vein in your arm using a small needle. The test usually takes less than five minutes and you may feel a slight sting when the needle goes in or out.

**Preparation for the Test**

You don't need any special preparations for an allergy blood test, but you may need to stop taking certain medicines such as antihistamines before the test. Inform your provider about everything you take.

**Risks of the Test**

There is very little risk to having an allergy blood test. You may experience slight pain or bruising at the spot where the needle was inserted, but most symptoms go away quickly.

**Interpreting Results**

A high total IgE test result means you may have some kind of allergy, but the results don't show what you're allergic to or how serious your allergy may be. A specific IgE test result that is high means you may be allergic to the allergen tested, but the amount of IgE measured doesn't predict how serious your allergy may be.

**Treatment Plan**

If the results from either type of test show that you could have an allergy, your provider may refer you to an allergy specialist or recommend a treatment plan. Your treatment plan will depend on what you are allergic to and how serious your symptoms are.

**Is There Anything Else I Need to Know?**

Allergy blood tests may not always be accurate. Sometimes, the results may say you have an allergy when you actually don't (false positive), which can happen if your body is having a slight reaction to substances in certain foods that you may have eaten before the test. Higher amounts of IgE may also be caused by smoking or a parasitic infection.

It's uncommon for a blood test to show that you don't have an allergy when you actually do (false negative). Depending on your medical history and symptoms, your provider may order an allergy skin test with an allergy blood test, or you may have a skin test alone.

---

**Allergy Blood Test**

Are you considering an allergy blood test? This article will guide you through the process and help you understand what to expect.

**What is an Allergy Blood Test?**

An allergy blood test measures the levels of allergen-specific IgE antibodies in your blood. It's a simple, painless procedure that can help diagnose allergies and monitor treatment effectiveness.

**How Does it Work?**

The test involves drawing a small sample of blood from a vein in your arm. The blood is then sent to a laboratory where it's tested for the presence of allergen-specific IgE antibodies. The results are usually available within 24-48 hours.

**What Can I Expect During the Test?**

The testing process typically takes around 30 minutes to an hour. You'll be seated comfortably, and a healthcare professional will insert a needle into a vein in your arm to collect a blood sample. You may feel a slight pinch or discomfort during the procedure, but it's usually mild.

**What Do the Results Mean?**

The results of your allergy blood test will show the levels of allergen-specific IgE antibodies in your blood. If the levels are high, it may indicate an allergic reaction. Your healthcare provider will interpret the results and discuss them with you.

**When is an Allergy Blood Test Ordered?**

Your healthcare provider may order an allergy blood test if:

* You have a history of allergies or asthma
* You're experiencing symptoms such as itching, hives, or difficulty breathing
* You've been exposed to potential allergens and are concerned about your reaction

**What Are the Benefits of an Allergy Blood Test?**

An allergy blood test offers several benefits, including:

* Accurate diagnosis of allergies
* Monitoring treatment effectiveness
* Identifying potential allergens that may cause reactions

**How Can I Prepare for the Test?**

To prepare for your allergy blood test, make sure to:

* Arrive at least 30 minutes before your scheduled appointment
* Wear comfortable clothing and remove any jewelry that may interfere with the testing process
* Inform your healthcare provider about any medications you're taking or allergies you have

**What Should I Expect After the Test?**

After the test, your healthcare provider will discuss the results with you and provide guidance on next steps. If you have a positive result, they may recommend further testing or treatment to manage your allergy.

Remember, an allergy blood test is a simple, painless procedure that can help you better understand your allergies and take control of your health.

title: Allergy Skin Test: MedlinePlus Medical Test
content:
**Allergy Skin Test**

**What is it?**

An allergy skin test helps find out what is causing your allergic reaction by exposing your skin to allergy-causing substances known as allergens.

**How does it work?**

Your immune system is your body's defense system. It usually fights germs. But when you have an allergy, your immune system sees a harmless substance, like dust or pollen, as a threat. Your immune system responds to this "threat" and causes an allergic reaction. Symptoms of an allergic reaction can range from sneezing and a stuffy nose to a life-threatening condition known as anaphylactic shock.

**What happens during the test?**

You will most likely get tested by an allergist or a dermatologist. You may get one or more of the following allergy skin tests:

*   An allergy scratch test, also known as a skin prick test, is the most common allergy skin test.
*   During the test:
    *   Your provider will place small drops of specific allergens on different areas on your skin, such as your forearm or back.
    *   Your provider will then lightly scratch or prick your skin through each drop.
    *   If you are allergic to any allergens, you will develop a hive or a small red bump, known as a wheal, at that area or areas within about 15 to 20 minutes.

**What do the results mean?**

Test results are usually reported as positive or negative:

*   If you have red bumps or swelling at any testing areas, the test is positive. This means you are probably allergic to those substances.
*   If you do not have red bumps or swelling at any of the testing areas, the test is negative. This means that you are probably not allergic to those substances.

**Is there anything else I need to know about an allergy skin test?**

Your provider may recommend an allergy blood test instead if you:

*   Have a skin condition such as severe eczema or psoriasis on your arms and back where the skin is usually tested
*   Are taking medicines that might interfere with test results
*   Have had a severe allergic reaction in the past

---

**Allergy Skin Test**

An allergy skin test is used to diagnose certain allergies by exposing your skin to suspected allergens and observing any allergic reactions.

**What is an Allergy?**

An allergy is an overreaction by your immune system to something that doesn't bother most people. Your immune system sees a harmless substance, like dust or pollen, as a threat and responds with an allergic reaction.

**Types of Hypersensitivity Reactions**

There are four main types of hypersensitivity reactions:

*   Type 1: causes common allergies such as dust mites, pollens, foods, and animal dander
*   Type II: involves antibodies that attack cells or proteins
*   Type III: involves the formation of antigen-antibody complexes that cause inflammation
*   Type IV: a delayed hypersensitivity reaction that can cause skin rashes or other symptoms

**Substances That Can Cause Allergic Reactions**

The test checks for reactions to specific allergens, including:

*   Pollen
*   Dust mites
*   Molds
*   Pet dander
*   Food
*   Insect bites and stings
*   Medicines
*   Household chemicals

**What Happens During an Allergy Skin Test?**

You will most likely get tested by an allergist or a dermatologist. You may get one or more of the following allergy skin tests:

*   An allergy scratch test, also known as a skin prick test, is the most common allergy skin test.
*   An intradermal test may be used to see if you are allergic to insect stings and the medicine penicillin.
*   A patch test checks to see if you have an allergic reaction to allergens that come in contact with your skin.

**Will I Need to Do Anything to Prepare for the Test?**

You may need to stop taking certain medicines before the test. These could include antihistamines and certain antidepressants. Your provider will tell you which medicines to avoid before your test and for how long. They may also ask about any products you use on your skin and if you are normally around animals.

**Are There Any Risks to the Test?**

There is very little risk to having allergy skin tests. The test itself is not painful. The most common side effect is red, itchy skin at the test areas.

---

**Allergy Skin Test**

**What is an allergy skin test?**

An allergy skin test, also known as a prick test or scratch test, is a medical test used to determine if you have an allergic reaction to certain substances. The test involves pricking your skin with a small amount of the suspected allergen and observing any reaction.

**Are there any risks to the test?**

There is very little risk to having allergy skin tests. The test itself is not painful. The most common side effect is red, itchy skin at the test areas. In very rare cases, an allergy skin test may cause anaphylactic shock. This is why skin tests must be done in a provider's office where emergency equipment is available.

**What do the results mean?**

Test results are usually reported as positive or negative:

* If you have red bumps or swelling at any testing areas, the test is positive. This means you are probably allergic to those substances.
* If you do not have red bumps or swelling at any of the testing areas, the test is negative. This means that you are probably not allergic to those substances.

**What happens if I am diagnosed with an allergy?**

If you are diagnosed with an allergy, your provider will recommend a treatment plan. The plan may include:

* Avoiding the allergen when possible
* Medicines
* Lifestyle changes such as reducing dust in your home

Your provider will consider your symptoms and medical history to understand the results of an allergy skin test. They may also want to do a physical exam.

**Is there anything else I need to know about an allergy skin test?**

Your provider may recommend an allergy blood test instead if you:

* Have a skin condition such as severe eczema or psoriasis on your arms and back where the skin is usually tested
* Are taking medicines that might interfere with test results
* Have had a severe allergic reaction in the past

If you are at risk for anaphylactic shock, you may need to carry an emergency epinephrine treatment with you at all times. Epinephrine is a drug used to treat severe allergies. It comes in a device called an epinephrine auto-injector that contains a premeasured amount of epinephrine. If you experience symptoms of anaphylactic shock, you should inject the device into your skin and call 911.

**References**

* Abbas M, Moussa M, Akel H. Type I Hypersensitivity Reaction. 2023 Jul 17.
* American Academy of Allergy Asthma & Immunology [Internet]. Milwaukee (WI): American Academy of Allergy Asthma & Immunology; c2024. Allergy Defined;
* American College of Allergy Asthma & Immunology [Internet]. Arlington Heights (IL): American College of Allergy Asthma & Immunology; c2024. Anaphylaxis;
* Cleveland Clinic: Health Library: Diagnostics & Testing [Internet]. Cleveland (OH): Cleveland Clinic; c2023. Allergy Skin Test;
* Mayo Clinic [Internet]. Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; c1998-2024. Allergy skin tests: Overview;
* Merck Manual Consumer Version [Internet]. Kenilworth (NJ): Merck & Co., Inc.; c2024. Overview of Allergic Reactions;

Note: The references provided are a selection of the original sources cited in the text, and may not be an exhaustive list.

---

**Allergy Skin Test**

Are you curious about allergy skin tests? In this article, we'll explore what they are, how they work, and what to expect during the test.

**What is an Allergy Skin Test?**

An allergy skin test, also known as a prick test or scratch test, is a medical test used to diagnose allergies. During the test, a small amount of an allergen (such as pollen, dust mites, or pet dander) is placed on your skin, and then pricked or scratched into the skin with a tiny needle.

**How Does it Work?**

When you're exposed to an allergen, your immune system reacts by releasing histamine, which causes symptoms like itching, redness, and swelling. The allergy skin test measures your body's reaction to specific allergens by checking for these symptoms on your skin.

**What to Expect During the Test**

The test typically takes 15-30 minutes to complete. You'll be seated comfortably, and a healthcare professional will place small amounts of different allergens on your skin using a device called a prick tester or scratch tester. The pricked or scratched area will be observed for any reaction, which can take anywhere from 10-20 minutes.

**Types of Allergic Reactions**

There are four main types of allergic reactions:

* **Type I**: Immediate hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by symptoms like itching, redness, and swelling.
* **Type II**: Antibody-dependent cytotoxic hypersensitivity reaction, where antibodies attack cells or tissues.
* **Type III**: Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, where immune complexes (antibodies attached to antigens) accumulate in tissues and cause inflammation.
* **Type IV**: Delayed hypersensitivity reaction, which occurs 48-72 hours after exposure to an allergen.

**Related Health Topics**

* Allergy
* Anaphylaxis
* Hay Fever
* Immune System and Disorders

**Related Medical Tests**

* Allergy Blood Test
* Celiac Disease Screening
* Food Allergy Testing

title: Allergy shots: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Allergy Shots**

An allergy shot is a medicine that is injected into your body to treat allergy symptoms.

**What are Allergy Shots?**

An allergy shot contains a small amount of an allergen. This is a substance that causes an allergic reaction. Examples of allergens include:

* Mold spores
* Dust mites
* Animal dander
* Pollen
* Insect venom

Your health care provider gives you the shots for 3 to 5 years. This series of allergy shots may help reduce your allergy symptoms.

Work with your provider to identify which allergens are causing your symptoms. This is often done through allergy skin testing or blood tests. Only the allergens you are allergic to are in your allergy shots.

Allergy shots are only one part of an allergy treatment plan. You may also take allergy medicines while having allergy shots. Your provider may recommend that you reduce your exposure to allergens, as well.

**How do Allergy Shots Work?**

Allergy symptoms occur when your immune system tries to attack an allergen in your body. When this happens, your body creates mucus. This can cause bothersome symptoms in the nose, eyes, and lungs.

Treatment with allergy shots is also called immunotherapy. When a small amount of an allergen is injected into your body, your immune system makes a substance called an antibody that blocks the allergen from causing symptoms.

After several months of shots, some or all of your symptoms may be relieved. Relief can last several years. For some people, allergy shots can prevent new allergies and reduce asthma symptoms.

**Who can Benefit From Allergy Shots?**

You may benefit from allergy shots if you have:

* Asthma that allergies make worse
* Allergic rhinitis, allergic conjunctivitis
* Insect bite sensitivity
* Eczema, a skin condition that a dust mite allergy can make worse

Allergy shots are effective for common allergens such as:

* Weed, ragweed, tree pollen
* Grass
* Mold or fungus
* Animal dander
* Dust mites
* Insect stings
* Cockroaches

Adults (including the older people) as well as children 5 years and older can receive allergy shots.

Your provider is not likely to recommend allergy shots for you if you:

* Have severe asthma.
* Have a heart condition.
* Take certain medicines, such as ACE inhibitors or beta-blockers.
* Are pregnant. Pregnant women should not begin allergy shots. But, they may be able to continue allergy shot treatment that was started before they became pregnant.

Food allergies are not treated with allergy shots.

**Getting Your Allergy Shots**

You will get your allergy shots at your provider's office. They are usually given in the upper arm. The typical schedule is:

* For the first 3 to 6 months, you receive shots about 1 to 3 times a week.
* For the next 3 to 5 years, you receive the shots less often, about every 4 to 6 weeks.

Keep in mind that many visits are needed to get the full effects of this treatment. Your provider will assess your symptoms now and then to help decide when you can stop receiving the shots.

**Side Effects**

An allergy shot may cause a reaction on the skin, such as redness, swelling, and itching. Some people have mild nasal stuffiness or a runny nose.

Though rare, an allergy shot can also cause a severe life-threatening allergic reaction called anaphylaxis. Because of this, you may need to stay in your provider's office for 30 minutes after your shot to check for this reaction.

You may also need to take an antihistamine or another medicine before your allergy shot appointments. This may prevent reactions to the shot at the injection site, but it does not prevent anaphylaxis.

Reactions to allergy shots can be treated in your provider's office right away.

---
